results.title: Late News
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Office of Intellectual Disability Services. Early Intervention Resource Unit
results.brief_description: Highlights the impact a late diagnosis of a developmental delay has on parents and the family. The program illustrates how early intervention services provide information, support, resources and individual programs in order to promote a child’s development.

results.title: Latcho drom : safe journey = Latcho drom : bonne route
results.creator_credit: Tony Gatlif, Michele Ray-Gavras and K G Productions
results.brief_description: A masterpiece by Tony Gatlif is a “docu-musical” which explores the rich cultural, social heritage of the world’s Gypsies. The program is a political statement about the persecution suffered by Gypsies but is presented as a celebration of their music, dance and song from the around the globe. Singers, dancers and musicians from India, Egypt, Turkey, Romania, Hungary, Slovakia, France and Spain are featured. This is an energetic, powerful, joyous experience.
results.title_for_label: Latcho drom : safe journey = Latcho drom : bonne route

results.title: Last paradise. Parts 1-3
results.creator_credit: Gian Manara and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: An educational documentary in three parts, ‘Last Paradise’ examines the contrasts between contemporary and traditional lifestyles in Papua New Guinea through the lives of flight crew members working for the country’s national airline, Air Niugini. While they enjoy the privileged lifestyles of international travellers, these men and women return each year to the villages and tribes to which they belong. The film makers contrast the work and leisure activities of the flight crew personnel abroad with the traditional culture, lore, and tribal values that continue to be the mainstay of the villages they come from to comment on the changes that are facing the inhabitants of Papua New Guinea and its surrounding islands at the end of the twentieth century.

results.title: Laser: the light of the future
results.creator_credit: Mauri Goldberg, National Educational Television and Prism Productions
results.brief_description: Describes the contribution of Dr Arthur Schawlow, head of the Department of Physics at Stanford University to the development of the ruby laser. An electronic organ coupled to an oscilloscope helps show why getting light “in step” is so difficult. A working model of atoms demonstrates how ordinary light is produced and how laser light is generated and controlled.

results.title: Laser safety
results.creator_credit: Barry Pollack and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description: Introduces the laser, illustrating the properties which make it useful, but explaining that it can be harmful to biological tissue. Demonstrates safety measures to prevent injury to eyes and skin.

results.title: Laser
results.brief_description: Light Amplification of Stimulated Emission of Radiation: this is the laser, the new wonder tool that can bore holes in steel, perform delicate eye operations and carry thousands of simultaneous telephone conversations and television channels. Communications with men on the moon may well be by means of a laser beam, and there is speculation about their use as “death rays” to bring down missiles in flight.

results.title: Larsen and Lewers
results.creator_credit: Dinah Van Dugteren and Crafts Council of Australia
results.brief_description: Presents the lives and works of jewellery making couple, Helge Larsen and Darani Lewers. Shows the way they work and their ideas on jewellery and craft.

results.title: Laplanders
results.brief_description: Photographed by Swedish cameraman and film producer Arne Sucksdorff, this documentary observes the activities of the reindeer-tending Laplanders of northern Scandinavia. We see a family packing up from the mountainous summer fishing camp and crossing the high country moors with pack reindeers. When they reach their home the herd reindeers are gathered and many of the males slaughtered, every part of the body being used for food, shelter, clothing and implements. Three generations of the one family are shown.

results.title: Language of design
results.brief_description: Illustrates how Australian textile designers are finding inspiration from the local scene. Samples of sea shells, driftwood, dead twigs from a tea-tree, and other such mateerials collected on the Australian beach, are used in the studio to provide motifs for typically Australian textile designs. A series of such designs are effectively displayed by artistically draped samples.
